Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of John Ashe's death and implies that it may have been related to testifying against the Clintons, when in fact there is no evidence to support this.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to back up the assertion that John Ashe's death was not accidental or related to the Clintons.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that John Ashe's death was not accidental and that he was going to testify against the Clintons, without providing any solid evidence or basis for these assumptions.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores the alternative explanation that John Ashe's death was ruled an accident and there is no evidence linking it to any foul play or involvement of the Clintons.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that John Ashe was not scheduled to testify against the Clintons and there is no mention of them in the complaint against him.
Falters at times: The claim falters by presenting a conspiracy theory without providing credible evidence or sources to support it.
Understate: The claim understates the actual circumstances of John Ashe's death by suggesting there may be more to it than an accidental barbell crushing his throat, when no evidence supports this.
